visualization.title: How We Visualize This Planet
visualization.intro: Our planet visualizations are generated procedurally using real scientific data from NASA's Exoplanet Archive. Here's how different properties influence what you see:

density.title: Density
density.description: Determines surface texture and composition. High-density worlds appear more rugged with retained impact craters (strong gravity holds surface features). Low-density "puffy" planets have smoother, more volatile-rich appearances.

insolation.title: Insolation Flux
insolation.description: The energy received from the host star. High insolation creates volcanic surfaces, lava glow, and active atmospheres. Low insolation produces ice coverage and frozen landscapes.

starTemp.title: Star Temperature
starTemp.description: Affects the lighting color. Planets around red dwarf stars have a warm orange tint, while those orbiting hot blue stars appear cooler and bluer.

planetType.title: Planet Type
planetType.description: Determines the base shader: Gas Giants show banded atmospheres with storms, Ice Giants have smooth blue-green methane atmospheres, and Rocky planets display terrain, craters, and possible atmospheres.

visualization.disclaimer: Note: These visualizations are artistic interpretations based on scientific data, not actual photographs. Each planet's unique seed ensures consistent appearance across sessions.

flagDescriptions.habitableZone: This planet orbits within the habitable zone ‚Äî the region around a star where liquid water could exist on the surface.
flagDescriptions.earthLike: This planet has characteristics similar to Earth: rocky composition, similar size, and potentially habitable conditions.
flagDescriptions.topCandidate: Among the best candidates for potential habitability based on multiple factors including temperature, size, and stellar environment.
flagDescriptions.potentiallyRocky: Based on its mass and radius, this planet likely has a rocky composition similar to Earth, Mars, or Venus.
flagDescriptions.earthLikeInsolation: This planet receives a similar amount of energy from its star as Earth does from the Sun (0.5-2.0√ó Earth's insolation).
flagDescriptions.hotJupiter: A gas giant orbiting very close to its star, resulting in extreme surface temperatures and rapid orbital periods.
flagDescriptions.hotNeptune: A Neptune-sized planet orbiting close to its star, experiencing intense stellar radiation.
flagDescriptions.ultraHot: Surface temperature exceeds 2000K ‚Äî hot enough to vaporize most metals and rocks.
flagDescriptions.frozenWorld: An extremely cold world where surface temperatures are too low for liquid water, likely covered in ice.
flagDescriptions.ultraDense: This planet has exceptionally high density, suggesting a composition dominated by heavy elements like iron.
flagDescriptions.puffy: A low-density planet with an extended atmosphere, likely inflated by intense stellar heating.
flagDescriptions.superMassive: An exceptionally massive planet, significantly larger than Jupiter.
flagDescriptions.lightweight: A very low-mass planet (less than half Earth's mass), possibly with a thin atmosphere or none at all.
flagDescriptions.ultraShortPeriod: Completes an orbit in less than one Earth day, experiencing extreme tidal forces and stellar radiation.
flagDescriptions.longPeriod: Takes over 1000 days to complete one orbit, existing far from its host star.
flagDescriptions.eccentricOrbit: Follows a highly elliptical orbit, experiencing significant variations in distance from its star.
flagDescriptions.circularOrbit: Follows a nearly circular orbit, maintaining a consistent distance from its star.
flagDescriptions.tidallyLocked: One side of this planet likely always faces its star, creating permanent day and night hemispheres.
flagDescriptions.circumbinary: Orbits around two stars, like Tatooine in Star Wars. Experiences complex gravitational dynamics.
flagDescriptions.multiPlanet: Part of a system with multiple confirmed planets orbiting the same star.
flagDescriptions.richSystem: Belongs to a planetary system with 4 or more confirmed planets.
flagDescriptions.multiStar: Located in a system with multiple stars (binary, triple, or more).
flagDescriptions.veryNearby: Less than 65 light-years from Earth ‚Äî one of our closest exoplanet neighbors.
flagDescriptions.nearby: Within 163 light-years of Earth, making it a relatively close interstellar neighbor.
flagDescriptions.solarAnalog: Orbits a star very similar to our Sun in temperature, size, and luminosity.
flagDescriptions.redDwarfHost: Orbits a red dwarf (M-type star), the most common type of star in the galaxy.
flagDescriptions.youngSystem: Part of a stellar system less than 1 billion years old ‚Äî still in its cosmic youth.
flagDescriptions.ancientSystem: Part of a stellar system over 10 billion years old ‚Äî older than most stars in our galaxy.
flagDescriptions.metalRich: Host star has high metallicity, which correlates with increased planet formation.
flagDescriptions.metalPoor: Host star has low metallicity, suggesting the system formed from primordial gas.
flagDescriptions.transiting: This planet passes in front of its star from our viewpoint, enabling detailed atmospheric studies.
flagDescriptions.hasRvData: Detected or confirmed using radial velocity measurements, which track the star's wobble caused by the planet.
flagDescriptions.hasTtv: Shows Transit Timing Variations ‚Äî changes in transit timing that reveal gravitational interactions with other bodies.
flagDescriptions.controversial: The existence or properties of this planet are debated among astronomers.

about.title: About
about.subtitle: Exploring 6,000+ confirmed worlds beyond our solar system

1992.title: First Exoplanets
1992.desc: Wolszczan & Frail discover the first confirmed exoplanets orbiting a pulsar, proving planets exist beyond our solar system.

1995.title: 51 Pegasi b
1995.desc: Mayor & Queloz detect the first exoplanet around a Sun-like star, earning them the 2019 Nobel Prize in Physics.

2009.title: Kepler Launches
2009.desc: NASA's Kepler space telescope begins its mission, eventually discovering over 2,700 confirmed exoplanets.

2016.title: Proxima Centauri b
2016.desc: Discovery of an Earth-sized planet in the habitable zone of our nearest stellar neighbor, just 4.2 light-years away.

2018.title: TESS Mission
2018.desc: The Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite begins an all-sky survey, finding planets around the brightest nearby stars.

today.title: 5,700+ Worlds
today.desc: We've now confirmed thousands of exoplanets, with many more candidates awaiting verification. The search continues.

project.title: Project Evolution
project.author_message: Greetings, Travelers! Guinetik here üë©‚ÄçüöÄ, your guide to the stars and beyond. I'm a software engineer and space enthusiast, and this project is a labor of love. It started as a way to learn Firebase ‚Äî I thought, why not use NASA's exoplanet dataset to build a TripAdvisor for the stars, where future space travelers could leave reviews about the planets they visit? We began with TESS data and a simple catalog. Then I wanted to learn Three.js, so I gave this old project a complete makeover ‚Äî adding 3D procedural planets, custom shaders, habitability scoring, and much more. Welcome aboard!
